An Elephant‚Äôs Trunk Is Covered in Whiskers‚Äîand They‚Äôre Unlike Those on Any Other Animal, a New Study Suggests
Hundreds of the specialized hairs help the poor-sighted creatures navigate the world
Elephants are famous for their dexterous trunks, which the animals use to eat, drink, trumpet and breathe. If you take a close look at the iconic appendage‚Äîan elongated nose and upper lip‚Äîyou‚Äôll see that it‚Äôs covered in about 1,000 whiskers, sensitive hairs that help the poor-sighted creatures navigate the world.
Now, researchers have conducted a deep dive on the structure of elephant whiskers‚Äîwhich seem to be unique among animals‚Äîand may have figured out how they work. An elephant whisker gradually goes from soft at the tip to rigid at the base, which might amplify incoming touch signals and help the huge animals carefully manipulate objects, according to a study published February 10 in the journal Science.
‚ÄúEach whisker on their trunk acts as a tactile sensory organ, extending their tactile range,‚Äù says study co-author Andrew Schulz, a biomechanist at the Max Planck Institute for Intelligent Systems in Germany, to Reuters‚Äô Will Dunham. ‚ÄúThey constantly feel their way through their surroundings with their trunks, searching for food and exchanging social touch.‚Äù
Many animals with whiskers, including cats and rats, can move them around using muscles in the skin at the bases of the specialized hairs. But elephants lack these muscles. ‚ÄúIf elephant trunk whiskers can‚Äôt move, there‚Äôs probably something built into them that allows them to‚Äù work similarly as the other creatures‚Äô whiskers, Schulz tells the New York Times‚Äô Alexa Robles-Gil.
So, Schulz and his colleagues studied donated whiskers from baby and adult Asian elephants that had naturally died. While past work on these sensory organs has focused on their middles, the team extensively examined the entire lengths of the hairs.
Did you know? The Smithsonian‚Äôs National Zoo recently welcomed a baby Asian elephant
For the first time in almost 25 years, an Asian elephant was born at the Zoo. The female calf was born on February 2 and just received her name, Linh Mai, which means ‚Äúspirit blossom‚Äù in Vietnamese.
A high-powered microscope and CT scans revealed that each whisker had an oblong cross-section that was wider and porous at the base and thinner toward the tip, resembling a blade of grass. The holes at one end probably aid with shock absorption, helping the whiskers last for a lifetime, since they don‚Äôt regrow if lost, Schulz tells the Times. Analyzing stiffness showed that the hairs are more rigid where they meet the trunk and softer at the opposite end. For comparison, rat whiskers are circular, mostly solid, stiff throughout their lengths and can regenerate if trimmed.
Elephant whiskers are like ‚Äúaliens,‚Äù Schulz tells the Washington Post‚Äôs Sarah Kaplan. ‚ÄúIf you try to compare them to any other whisker structure, they‚Äôre basically different in every single way.‚Äù
To understand what those characteristics mean for an elephant‚Äôs experience, the team 3D printed a large replica of a whisker and banged it against objects. Hitting various contact points on the ‚Äúwhisker wand‚Äù felt different, the team found. ‚ÄúTapping the railing with different parts of the whisker wand felt distinct‚Äîsoft and gentle at the tip, and sharp and strong at the base,‚Äù says study co-author Katherine Kuchenbecker, a mechanical engineer at the Max Planck Institute for Intelligent Systems, in a statement. ‚ÄúI didn‚Äôt need to look to know where the contact was happening; I could just feel it.‚Äù
Combining all the characteristics in computer simulations revealed that a whisker with a stiff base that transitions to a soft tip should help an elephant know where an object is touching along the specialized hairs. That might explain how the creatures can carefully move items as fragile as a tortilla chip or as heavy as a tree, despite their poor eyesight.
‚ÄúWe all have the problem of needing to sense things in our environment, but there‚Äôs a multitude of ways you can solve this problem,‚Äù study co-author Lena Kaufmann, a neurobiologist at Humboldt University in Germany, tells the Washington Post. ‚ÄúAnd I think that‚Äôs the very fascinating thing.‚Äù
Previous elephant research has mainly focused on ecology and behavior, but more studies are beginning to zoom in on specific aspects of these animals, John Hutchinson, an evolutionary biomechanist at the Royal Veterinary College in England, who wasn‚Äôt involved with the research, tells the Times.
The researchers highlighted the differences between elephant whiskers and those of other animals, including domestic cats, whose specialized hairs are more solid and are covered in scales. ‚ÄúThat impressed me,‚Äù Hutchinson says to the outlet. ‚ÄúI just always thought, ‚ÄòWhiskers‚Äîwell, they‚Äôre just whiskers.‚Äô‚Äù

articles.content:
These Emily Carr Paintings Will Make You Experience the Beauty of British Columbia‚Äôs Landscapes in a Completely New Way
An exhibition at the Vancouver Art Gallery examines the artist‚Äôs attempts to capture nature‚Äôs true essence, which she described as ‚Äúthe green idea or ideal‚Äù
A sprawling exhibition of lush, colorful paintings by Emily Carr is now on view at the Vancouver Art Gallery. Titled ‚ÄúThat Green Ideal: Emily Carr and the Idea of Nature,‚Äù the show is an examination of the 20th-century artist‚Äôs complex connection with the Pacific Northwest.
The gallery boasts the world‚Äôs largest Carr collection, and this show is its ‚Äúmost comprehensive exhibition of Emily Carr‚Äôs work in more than 20 years,‚Äù according to a recent statement. Featuring paintings, drawings, journals and archival materials, ‚ÄúThat Green Ideal‚Äù was named for a phrase found in the artist‚Äôs own writings. The show is an expression of her ‚Äúlifelong effort to capture not just the appearance of nature, but its perceived inner essence,‚Äù per the museum.
‚ÄúFind the forms you desire to express your purpose,‚Äù the artist wrote in a journal in 1931. ‚ÄúWhen you have succeeded in getting them as near as you can to express your idea, never leave them but push further on and on, strengthening and emphasizing those forms to enclose that green idea or ideal.‚Äù
Carr was born in Victoria, British Columbia, in 1871. She began her artistic education at the California School of Design in San Francisco in 1890 before returning to Victoria to teach art classes. Once she saved enough money, she continued her studies at the Westminster School of Art in London. She then took a short but formative trip to Paris, ‚Äúwhere she developed a distinctive post-Impressionist style and a Fauvist-inspired palette that would define much of her later work,‚Äù per the statement.
Upon returning to Canada, Carr traveled to the Haida Gwaii archipelago, which has been home to the Haida people for thousands of years, and applied French influences to subjects such as totem poles. However, audiences didn‚Äôt respond to these artworks when they were exhibited in 1913.
In 1927, Carr‚Äôs work was featured in the National Gallery of Canada‚Äôs ‚ÄúExhibition of Canadian West Coast Art: Native and Modern,‚Äù which revived her career. Throughout the 15 years that followed, Carr created the ‚Äúpowerful, swirling landscapes and forest scenes that remain her most celebrated achievements,‚Äù according to the gallery.
‚ÄúEmily Carr created a way of seeing [British Columbia‚Äôs] landscapes that people hadn‚Äôt quite experienced before‚Äîone grounded in spatiality, where you‚Äôre not just looking at the forest, but feel as though your nose is right up against it,‚Äù says exhibition curator Richard Hill in the statement. ‚ÄúHer vision was so compelling that we now tend to take it for granted, overlooking how her paintings continue to shape our visual understanding of the region.‚Äù
According to a September statement from the gallery, Carr spent time in nature both as a careful observer and a seeker of spiritual transcendence. Based on later writings about her artistic process, the artist appears to have been driven by a ‚Äúmission to depict the essence, in an original way ‚Ä¶ of her encounters with the region‚Äôs dense rainforests.‚Äù
Just as she connected with nature, Carr also felt a connection with the region‚Äôs Indigenous communities, which was later criticized as cultural appropriation. In journal entries, the artist sometimes ‚Äúidentified as an Indigenous person, despite being from a white settler background,‚Äù wrote JSTOR Daily‚Äôs Emily Zarevich in 2025. The exhibition features commentary on this subject by Haida scholar Marcia Crosby.
The show also examines how Carr‚Äôs approach was influenced by modernist ideas like vitalism and primitivism, which she learned about in France, Hill tells the Art Newspaper‚Äôs Hadani Ditmars. Such concepts informed ‚Äúthe change in her final works, from attempting to achieve spatial proximity to nature to imagining herself at one with nature.‚Äù
In ‚ÄúThat Green Ideal,‚Äù Hill is aiming to explore the tension between Carr‚Äôs desire to commune with nature and the larger cultural and artistic frameworks that influenced her paintings. As the curator said in the September statement, ‚ÄúWhat interests me is the extent to which Carr was not, intellectually speaking, alone in the forest as she conceived these works.‚Äù
The exhibition also features some of Carr‚Äôs rarely seen artworks on paper. These pieces are quite delicate, and they can‚Äôt be exposed to too much light. To limit exposure, the gallery will swap out its selection of works on paper halfway through the exhibition‚Äôs run.
‚ÄúIn particular, we have an amazing collection of charcoal drawings that we don‚Äôt often get to show, and over the course of the exhibition we‚Äôll get almost all of them on display,‚Äù Hill tells the Art Newspaper. ‚ÄúThey are stunning. ‚Ä¶ Likewise, the very expressive paintings on paper she did later in her career, mixing oil paint with gasoline to create a very fluid style.‚Äù
Quick fact: A rediscovered Emily Carr painting
After an art dealer purchased a painting for $50, it was identified as an original artwork by Carr‚Äîand in 2024, it sold at auction for $250,000.Carr died in 1945, and her renown has only grown in the decades since. Her work has been displayed in countless exhibitions, including the Beyeler Foundation‚Äôs recent ‚ÄúNorthern Lights,‚Äù which also included paintings by Edvard Munch. Last year, her 1935 painting Fir Trees fetched $576,000 at auction, much more than its estimated price of $275,000 to $375,000.
‚ÄúIf ever there was a heroine of true grit in the history of art it was Emily Carr,‚Äù wrote the Observer art critic Laura Cumming in 2014. ‚ÄúCarr‚Äôs landscapes of the high skies, wild bays and deep forests of the Pacific west coast of Canada‚Äîwhispering with sound, radiant with inner movement and mysterious light‚Äîare as exhilarating as the places they represent.‚Äù
Though Carr is often compared to Georgia O‚ÄôKeeffe, who was painting nature scenes around the same time, Cumming wrote that she ‚Äúhas more in common with her fellow outsider Vincent van Gogh.‚Äù
‚ÄúThat Green Ideal: Emily Carr and the Idea of Nature‚Äù is on view at the Vancouver Art Gallery through November 8, 2026.

articles.author: Reda√ß√£o
articles.excerpt:
Five Things to Know About ‚ÄòWuthering Heights,‚Äô Author Emily Bront√´‚Äôs Only Novel
The famed 1847 book inspired numerous adaptations, including a new version directed by Emerald Fennell in theaters this...
articles.content:
Five Things to Know About ‚ÄòWuthering Heights,‚Äô Author Emily Bront√´‚Äôs Only Novel
The famed 1847 book inspired numerous adaptations, including a new version directed by Emerald Fennell in theaters this week
In 1847, English writer Emily Bront√´ published her first and only novel, Wuthering Heights. While it originally shocked and baffled critics, it eventually became a beloved classic. Multiple film adaptations have hit the screen, such as the 1939 iteration starring Laurence Olivier and Merle Oberon as the novel‚Äôs legendary leads, Heathcliff and Catherine (Cathy) Earnshaw, and Peter Kosminsky‚Äôs 1992 version starring Ralph Fiennes and Juliette Binoche.
More recently, a 2011 adaptation featured actors James Howson and Kaya Scodelario. And this week, director Emerald Fennell‚Äôs Wuthering Heights debuts with Margot Robbie as Cathy and Jacob Elordi as Heathcliff. The movie has renewed interest in the novel, and as Forbes‚Äô Sofia Chierchio reports, more than 70,000 copies were sold across all print editions in January.
As the latest Wuthering Heights film enters theaters, here are some helpful facts about Bront√´ and her novel to keep in mind when watching.
Who was Emily Bront√´?
Born in Thornton, Yorkshire, on July 30, 1818, Bront√´ was the daughter of a respected church curate, Patrick Bront√´, and his wife, Maria Branwell. Along with her six siblings, she spent much of her childhood in a parsonage at Haworth, a small village near the Yorkshire moors. During this time, she experienced a series of significant losses. She was only 3 when her mother died, and her older sisters Maria and Elizabeth died from tuberculosis a few years later. Bront√´ remained close with her surviving siblings, her sisters Charlotte and Anne and her brother, Patrick Branwell, known simply as Branwell. The group often read, wrote and shared stories with one another.
In 1846, Bront√´ and her sisters released a book of poetry under male pen names, hoping to stave off criticism influenced by their gender. Titled Poems by Currer, Ellis and Acton Bell, the collection received positive press, but it was far from a commercial success, reportedly only selling two copies. A year later, Bront√´ published her novel, Wuthering Heights, under the name Ellis Bell. She did not live long enough to see what ultimately became of her book, dying in 1848 at age 30 from tuberculosis.
Quick fact: Exploring the Bront√´ legacy
The Bront√´ Parsonage Museum in Haworth houses the world‚Äôs largest collection of artifacts related to the literary family.
What is Wuthering Heights about?
The novel opens with Lockwood, Heathcliff‚Äôs new tenant, who asks a housekeeper, Nelly Dean, to tell him more about his landlord. Her account frames the central narrative, which includes a large ensemble of characters, though the plot is centered around Catherine and Heathcliff. Their interactions make up the bulk of the first half of the novel, and the second half examines the consequences of their chaos, largely through the lens of their extended family and acquaintances.
The coddled daughter of a wealthy landowner, Cathy resides at the Wuthering Heights estate with her family. She is described as beautiful, and she has an unpredictable, lively spirit, often vacillating between arrogance and anger.
Heathcliff is an enigma when he arrives at Wuthering Heights. Cathy‚Äôs father, Mr. Earnshaw, brings him to his estate as a young orphan, the details of his background a mystery. He is referred to as a ‚Äúdark-skinned gipsy‚Äù and later described as ‚Äúdark almost as if it came from the devil.‚Äù Heathcliff is scorned for his ambiguous, most likely nonwhite, racial identity and lower-class status.
After meeting as children, Cathy and Heathcliff become close companions, and their mutual obsession grows stronger when they get older. When her father dies, Cathy‚Äôs brother, Hindley, treats Heathcliff like a servant, periodically abusing and castigating him.
Cathy rejects the possibility of marriage with Heathcliff and marries the affluent Edgar Linton. Heathcliff swears revenge, leaving Wuthering Heights and returning years later as a prosperous gentleman, but his malevolence has only increased, and his violence touches everyone who once knew him.
What is the significance of the moors?
A moor, or moorland, is an expanse of open land, often recognizable by its rolling hills, low grass, bog moss and sparse tree growth. Heather and peat are other common elements of the landscape.
The English moors play a central role as the setting for the novel. Many scholars agree that the dramatically and meticulously rendered moors in Wuthering Heights are the very Yorkshire moors that Bront√´ and her siblings wandered in their youth.
Wuthering Heights is more tragedy than romance
Bront√´ was a voracious reader. She particularly enjoyed Romantic literature and regularly studied works by William Wordsworth, Percy Shelley and Lord Byron. Emerging in the late 18th century, Romanticism challenged earlier artistic conventions, such as Neoclassicism, that spotlighted order, balance and rationality. Instead, arbiters of Romanticism prioritized imaginative and emotional modes of being. An appreciation of nature in all its wildness was another crucial facet of the movement, as was a devotion to the mysterious and the bizarre.
In Wuthering Heights, Bront√´ embraces darkness, ferocity and the remote allure of the natural landscape. The Gothic classic is not, for many, a typical love story, nor a romance in the modern sense.
Bront√´‚Äôs novel was initially a critical failure
When Wuthering Heights was first published, critics were appalled.
A reviewer for Douglas Jerrold‚Äôs Weekly Newspaper wrote, ‚ÄúThe reader is ‚Ä¶ disgusted, almost sickened by details of cruelty, inhumanity and the most diabolical hate and vengeance.‚Äù
Another critic for Graham‚Äôs magazine fumed, ‚ÄúHow a human being could have attempted such a book as the present without committing suicide before he had finished a dozen chapters, is a mystery. It is a compound of vulgar depravity and unnatural horrors.‚Äù
Bront√´‚Äôs sister Charlotte‚Äîwho would become a literary heavyweight in her own right with Jane Eyre‚Äîstruggled with the backlash, mostly due to fears that their family would undergo permanent social ostracism. Anne similarly experienced condemnation for her novel, The Tenant of Wildfell Hall.
After her sisters died, Charlotte tried to defend their reputations, writing the ‚ÄúBiographical Notice of Ellis and Acton Bell‚Äù in 1850. In the account, she reworked Bront√´ into a more palatable persona, describing her as a na√Øve and impressionable woman who was not ‚Äúlearned.‚Äù This stood in stark contrast to who Bront√´ appeared to be: savvy, intellectual and educated. Yet Wuthering Heights unnerved the public‚Äîand Charlotte‚Äîto such an extent that her sister grew determined to change the conversation. It is rumored that she even burned the manuscript of Bront√´‚Äôs second novel.
But Bront√´‚Äôs legacy proudly lives on, inspiring (and terrifying) readers to this day. Despite its earlier critics, Wuthering Heights is now applauded as a feat of creative genius.

Will a Dazzling Display of Wildflowers Spread Across California This Spring?
Superblooms are rare events that occur when conditions perfectly align. Officials hope that visitors will be able to see brightly colored landscapes in the weeks ahead
Death Valley National Park, located in California‚Äôs Mojave Desert, is one of the hottest and driest places in the country. However, a rare event known as a superbloom may brighten up its barren terrain this spring.
‚ÄúBased on the sprouts we see, it looks quite possible there will be a superbloom,‚Äù the National Park Service (NPS) tells AccuWeather meteorologist Brian Lada. ‚ÄúThere are already nice fields of wildflowers blooming along the south end of Badwater Road.‚Äù
Superblooms only occur when specific weather conditions align, which is why they are such a rare spectacle. Environmental conditions must be primed months in advance.
According to the NPS, at least three factors are necessary for an impressive wildflower bloom: ‚Äúwell-spaced rainfall throughout the fall, winter and spring; sufficient warmth from the sun; and lack of drying winds.‚Äù
California officials recommend visiting the following locations for the best superbloom sightings: Anza-Borrego Desert State Park, Antelope Valley California Poppy Reserve State Natural Reserve, Red Rock Canyon State Park, Chino Hills State Park, Eastern Kern County Onyx Ranch State Vehicular Recreation Area, Hungry Valley State Vehicular Recreation Area, Saddleback Butte State Park and Arthur B. Ripley Desert Woodland State Park.
Some parks, like Anza-Borrego Desert State Park, started experiencing early blooms a few weeks ago. According to a January 23 statement from the park, visitors had spotted ‚Äúdesert sand verbena, primroses, desert sunflowers, apricot mallow and even desert lilies.‚Äù
Meanwhile, as of February 9, Carrizo Plain National Monument was already seeing ‚Äúyellows and splashes of orange, with more sprouting every day,‚Äù as monument manager Johna Hurl said in a statement.
Fun fact: Monitoring superbloom conditions
The Antelope Valley California Poppy Reserve, which expects peak bloom to occur between mid-March and May, has a live feed for visitors who want to observe changes to the landscape.
Death Valley‚Äôs last superbloom occurred in 2016, following an El Ni√±o pattern that brought heavy rain and flooding in the area. Before that, the region experienced these magnificent wildflower events in 2005 and 1998.
More recent superblooms have occurred elsewhere in California, including in 2023, when the vibrant colors could be seen from space. Another occurred in 2019, when tens of thousands of visitors flocked to see the springtime phenomenon.
Large numbers of tourists can damage wildflowers, which are ‚Äúone of the most important resources we have to ensure the resilience of California‚Äôs grasslands,‚Äù Valerie Eviner, an ecologist at the University of California, Davis, said in a statement in 2023. That year, Walker Canyon in Lake Elsinore closed in anticipation of the predicted superbloom.
However, conservationists hope that superblooms‚Äô breathtaking beauty will encourage the public to care more about protecting the environment.
‚ÄúNature is screaming through a megaphone, ‚ÄòLook how amazing I am; come and connect with me!‚Äô‚Äù Evan Meyer, executive director of the Theodore Payne Foundation, told the Washington Post‚Äôs Reis Thebault in 2023. ‚ÄúAnd it‚Äôs important that people connect to this, because if you don‚Äôt have a connection, you‚Äôre not going to care when it gets destroyed.‚Äù
With blooms predicted to intensify in the coming weeks, visitors can expect to see an abundance of flowers, including the desert gold, brown-eyed evening primrose, golden evening primrose, sand verbena and phacelia. Officials are encouraging observers to keep their distance in order to protect the landscape.
As Travel + Leisure‚Äôs Michael Cappetta writes, ‚ÄúVisitors to any wildflower site should ensure they explore responsibly, staying on designated trails and taking care not to tread on the blooms or pick any flowers.‚Äù

Earth‚Äôs Core Might Hold Dozens of Oceans Worth of Hydrogen, Hinting at the Origins of the Planet‚Äôs Vast Water Supply
Scientists have long debated whether most of Earth‚Äôs vital liquid was delivered via icy comets or was homemade
How Earth got its water has remained an open question for years. Some scientists suspect that much of it came from icy comets that pelted the planet during its youth. But now, new research supports another leading idea: A huge reservoir of hydrogen‚Äîwater‚Äôs main ingredient‚Äîmay have been hiding on Earth since the planet‚Äôs early formation, hinting that most of this vital liquid may have been homemade.
Earth‚Äôs core might contain between 9 and 45 times as much hydrogen as the ocean, according to a study published February 10 in the journal Nature Communications. Hydrogen there may have escaped into the planet‚Äôs other layers and reacted with oxygen, one of the most abundant elements in the mantle, to create water, study co-author Motohiko Murakami, a geodynamicist at ETH Zurich in Switzerland, tells Science News‚Äô Nikk Ogasa.
Quick fact: How big is the ocean?
Ocean water covers roughly 71 percent of Earth‚Äôs surface and contains about 321 million cubic miles of water.
Some 4.6 billion years ago, gas, rocks and dust clumped together to form Earth. In the baby planet‚Äôs high-pressure center, metals‚Äîprimarily iron and nickel‚Äîheated into liquid and started to swirl. But other elements exist there too.
Researchers have previously attempted to investigate how much hydrogen might be lurking in the core, but because of its depth and pressure, that work has largely relied on computer simulations and lab environments that mimic the conditions. And hydrogen is especially hard to quantify ‚Äúbecause it is the lightest and smallest element,‚Äù study co-author Dongyang Huang, an Earth and space scientist at Peking University in China, tells CNN‚Äôs Mindy Weisberger.
So, Huang, Murakami and their colleagues took a different approach to measure this tricky element. In the lab, they recreated Earth‚Äôs middle by wrapping iron, representing the core, in glass containing hydrogen, silicon and oxygen, which acted as the planet‚Äôs early ocean of molten rock. Samples were squeezed at extremely high pressures, up to 111 gigapascals, between diamonds and heated to a maximum of roughly 8,720 degrees Fahrenheit.
After the melted blobs cooled and solidified, the researchers tracked where hydrogen, silicon and oxygen atoms had gone within the iron. The analysis revealed that hydrogen and silicon had formed a specific structure, in which the two elements‚Äô atoms existed in a one-to-one ratio. Existing estimates of silicon in the core helped the team calculate the amount of hydrogen that should be present.
Hydrogen makes up between 0.07 percent and 0.36 percent of the core‚Äôs weight, the researchers estimate, making it the planet‚Äôs largest store of the light element.
What‚Äôs more, that percentage might be an underestimate, Kei Hirose, a planetary scientist at the University of Tokyo in Japan who was not involved in the study, writes in an email to CNN. Hydrogen may have escaped as the pressure ramped down, which was not accounted for in the new work. And Hirose‚Äôs past research has hinted that the core contains a larger amount of hydrogen than the recent estimate, he tells the outlet.
Such a large hydrogen reserve in the core must have come about when the planet was forming, Hilke Schlichting, a planetary scientist at the University of California, Los Angeles, who was not involved in the research, tells Scientific American‚Äôs Stephanie Pappas. The discovery ‚Äúreally changes the way we think of where our water comes from,‚Äù she says.
